Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Age-Structured Foraging Models for a Diving Mammal: Incorporating Developmental Constraints into Habitat Use Decisions
Award.AbstractNarration: While it may seem like a matter of simple choices, feeding is a complex event with many potential trade-offs. Current theory predicts that the goal of foraging is at least impart to maximize fitness, reproduction. However, to do this an individual must not only obtain food it must also avoid cost, such as being eaten itself. This means that foraging involves significant trade-offs. Therefore, to understand these types of trade-offs it is necessary to examine feeding within the boarder contexts of ecological, developments, and physiologically, as well as, behavioral conditions. Young animals have different skills than adults, and also they may have different constraints. The goal of this study is to develop a model that can address these factors using the data on diving capacity, habitat, and foraging behavior across different age groups of sea otters. The data do not involve direct manipulation of sea otters, instead they rely on using data being obtained form the US Geological Survey that has tagged sea otters already. The results form this research should have boarder application to general foraging models for other species and will provide practical information on habitat requirements that can be used in the conservation and management of sea otters. The results will also be made available to the public through the Monterey Bay Aquarium.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Southern sea otters (Enhydra lutris nereis) are a threatened marine mammal species along the coast of California that play an important role in promoting the health of nearshore ecosystems. We examined the influence of sex, reproductive status, and resource availability on the diving and foraging behavior of sea otters off the coast of California, in both food-limited (long-occupied, high sea otter density) and food-abundant (recently occupied, low sea otter density) locations. Our results revealed that both food availability and female reproductive status strongly influenced sea otter foraging behavior and effort. Among females with pups, behavioral changes were closely linked to pup developmental stage and were likely reflective of a pup’s age-specific energy demands and physiological capacities. Resource limitation necessitated a greater foraging effort by all individuals, regardless of sex or reproductive status, but females with young (≤10 weeks) pups exhibited the greatest proportional change in behavior as a consequence of resource limitation.  Females with very small pups in food-limited areas appeard unable to optimally modify their behavior in the first few weeks following birth, which may influence the likeihood of successful pup weaning. Indeed, females greatly restricted their foraging activity when caring for young pups, but this reduction was less pronounced in food-limited areas.  Furthermore, our data suggested that females with large pups in food-limited areas may be approaching a species-specific ceiling for percent time foraging, as time must be devoted to other important behaviors (e.g. resting, grooming, nursing pup) Ultimately, reproductive females in the central portion of the southern sea otter range appeared to be disproportionately impacted by food availability, and these females may have limited behavioral and physiological flexibility to adapt to further changes in food distribution and abundance.

 


Last Modified: 12/24/2015
Modified by: Nicole Thometz

Our results revealed that both food availability and female reproductive status strongly influenced sea otter foraging behavior and effort. Resource limitation necessitated a greater foraging effort by all individuals, regardless of sex or reproductive status, but females with young (≤10 weeks) pups exhibited the greatest proportional change in behavior as a consequence of resource limitation. Females with very small pups in food-limited areas appeard unable to optimally modify their behavior in the first few weeks following birth, which may influence the likeihood of successful pup weaning. Indeed, females greatly restricted their foraging activity when caring for young pups, but this reduction was less pronounced in food-limited areas.
